title: Sergei Baltacha (footballer, born 1979)
text:
Sergei Baltacha (born 28 July 1979) is a former <a href="association%20football">footballer</a>. Born in the USSR (now Ukraine), Baltacha represented Scotland at youth international level.
Club career.
He first played football in the <a href="Dynamo%20Kiev">Dynamo Kiev</a> academy, but began his professional career in Scotland, at <a href="St%20Mirren%20F.C.">St Mirren</a>, where he gained 3 caps for the <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland U-21 side</a>. After a trial at <a href="Portsmouth%20F.C.">Portsmouth</a> he joined <a href="Millwall%20F.C.">Millwall</a> in January 2003 and was released a year later, after which he had an unsuccessful trial with <a href="Queen%20of%20the%20South%20F.C.">Queen of the South</a>, and <a href="St%20Johnstone%20F.C.">St Johnstone</a> before signing with <a href="Petershill%20F.C.">Petershill</a> in 2004. He retired from professional football in 2005/2006.
International career.
Baltacha was eligible to play for Russia, Ukraine and under FIFA regulations at the time, the four <a href="Home%20nations">Home nations</a> as a British passport holder born outside of the United Kingdom with no British parental or grand-parental bloodlines. Baltacha Jr. had moved to the United Kingdom with his father, <a href="Sergei%20Pavlovich%20Baltacha">Sergei Pavlovich Baltacha</a>, when he signed for <a href="Ipswich%20Town%20F.C.">Ipswich Town</a> and at the age of 11 moved to Scotland when Baltacha Sr. signed for <a href="St%20Johnstone%20F.C.">St Johnstone</a> in May 1990. Having acquired a British passport, in 1999, he represented Scotland at U21 level against Lithuania.
Personal life.
His father, <a href="Sergei%20Pavlovich%20Baltacha">Sergei</a>, played football for the <a href="Soviet%20Union%20national%20football%20team">Soviet Union</a>, his mother, Olga, was a pentathlete and his sister, <a href="Elena%20Baltacha">Elena Baltacha</a>, was the former British number one for Women's tennis.
